newsitem.title: DUBAI: Middle East oil kings turn to gas.
newsitem.headline: Middle East oil kings turn to gas.

text.p: Middle East oil exporters are adding another string to their bow by developing their gas reserves to meet Asian power demand in the next century.
Gas, previously flared across the Middle East as a waste product, is now a high value commodity that could emerge as one of the financial foundations for many of the region's energy-dependent states.

Exporting gas trapped under the desert sands or shallow waters of the Gulf is being realised through multi-billion-dollar liquefied natural gas (LNG) projects and cross-border pipeline projects with the help of foreign backing.
The investments are being made to take advantage of forecasts of surging power generation demand for gas, particularly in South Korea and other thirsty Asian gas importers.

"Over the next 15 years, world LNG demand will approach seven percent a year, while total energy demand is expected to be less than two percent," Daniel Nelson, Mobil Corp's executive vice president for LNG development, told delegates at a gas conference in the United Arab Emirates earlier this month.
"Asia will continue to be the world's primary demand centre," Nelson said.
A flood of LNG and pipeline projects from Iran to Yemen are based on the abundant gas reserves held in the region, second only to those in Russia.
Iran's reserves are independently assessed at 742 trillion cubic feet, giving the Islamic republic a staggering reserve to production ratio of 595 years.
Qatar, which has the largest non-associated gas field outside the former Soviet Union, has a reserve production rate of 525 years.

The sultanate of Oman -- until now a medium-sized oil producer -- will take its major step into the gas export business on Wednesday when it signs a 25-year LNG supply deal with South Korea's Korea Gas Corp.
Qatar will start to reap the rewards of its first joint venture gas project with foreign firms when its Qatargas LNG project sends its first tanker to Japan in December.

Iran, sitting on the world's second largest reserves of gas behind Russia, is eyeing laying gas pipelines to Europe after signing a $23 billion supply deal with Turkey in August and is reviving plans for its own LNG project.
Oil giant Saudi Arabia is developing its gas base to fuel the kingdom's plans for an expanding petrochemical sector which is now the cornerstone of its industrialisation programme.
The gas trade could also become a part of the fruits of Middle East peace with plans to supply Israel with LNG from Qatar and natural gas from Egypt actively being promoted.

"Middle Eastern LNG supply will increase significantly over the next few years. Based only on contracted volumes, its share of total supply to Asia-Pacific markets will increase from seven percent in 1995 to around 25 percent by 2003," said Andrew Flower, British Petroleum's LNG business development manager.

Project designs fill the in-trays of state energy firms, while the same multinationals which developed the oil before the pan-Arab nationalisation programmes of the 1970s are frequent visitors looking to develop largely untapped gas deposits.

Though it may lack some of the romance attached to oil, LNG has a mystique and a financial complexity all of its own because of the vast investment sums required and the need to guarantee supply contracts long term -- some 25 years.
LNG is produced by freezing gas, mostly methane, to minus 160 Celsius in a sophisticated liquefaction plant and loading the frozen gas onto specialist tankers for export.

Insulated tankers with 40-metre-plus diameter domes sailing from Gulf ports to growing power markets in Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, India, China and Thailand is expected to become a common sight in the next decade.
These countries are facing increased power generation requirements to keep pace with growing economies and urban populations.
Backers of a new grassroots LNG plant face project costs of at least $6 billion, long construction lead times and lengthy though sustained pay-back schedules.
"The LNG business is more a way of life than a series of short-term ventures. Without a truly long-term corporate commitment, it is illogical to spend a dime", Mobil's Nelson said.
Middle East oil states have already understood the economic virtue of patience.
